author: By Maya C. Miller
title: Senate Passes Bill to Make Penalties Permanent for Fentanyl-Related Drugs
description: The measure, which passed with bipartisan support and minor changes, now heads back to the House. It is just the second legislative victory for the new Republican-controlled Congress.
content: The Senate on Friday approved legislation that would make permanent strict controls and harsh criminal penalties on fentanyl-related drugs. Several Democrats joined all Republicans in approving the bill, which because of minor changes now must pass the House again before it goes to President Trump’s desk.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Zhang
title: The Upside-Down Line That Tells the Story of the Stock Market Now
description: When President Trump entered his first term, stocks were steadily marching upward. This time, the trajectory has inverted.
content: The stock market has plunged since President Trump took office for a second time, a stark contrast to the early days of his first presidency. The S&P 500 index has fallen sharply since hitting a record high on Feb. 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Miller
title: The Pandemic Ruined High School for Them. They’re Learning to Live Again.
description: Stuck in their bedrooms, the class of 2021 missed important rites of passage — first job, first car, first date. Now young adults, they’re making up for what they missed at 16.
content: By the fall of 2020, many of the seniors at Oakland Technical High School had become nocturnal.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Supreme Court Revives Long-Running Nazi Art Restitution Case
description: The case involving a Pissarro is being sent back to federal court in California for review in light of a new state law, in a dispute between heirs and a Spanish museum.
content: One of the longest-running Nazi restitution cases, fiercely debated within the courts for two decades, seemed to have met its end last year when the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in California ruled against the plaintiffs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs and Emily Anthes
title: Who’s Afraid of Lab-Grown Meat?
description: Mississippi became the third state to ban cell-derived meat, a product not for sale in the United States. But not all livestock producers are opposed to cultivated protein.
content: Curious to try a lab-grown chicken sandwich? Don’t look to satiate your craving in Mississippi, which earlier this week moved to ban so-called cultivated or cell-derived meat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Abrams, Mark Landler, Rob Szypko, Carlos Prieto, Eric Krupke, Maria Byrne, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
title: Trump, Europe and the New World Order
description: The trans-Atlantic relationship that has characterized the post-World War II era appears to be breaking down.
content: In just a few weeks, the Trump administration has taken a hard line with allies such as Mexico and Canada. Now, a trade war is on the horizon with Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: Outrage in Australia After American Woman Grabs a Baby Wombat
description: A video of the online influencer snatching the joey from the side of its mother drew calls for her to be deported. She left the country Friday.
content: In times of tumult and uncertainty, a society can come together over resounding, unequivocal disdain against a common villain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: Explore the Met Museum With Gavin Creel and More Theater to Stream Now
description: Also available for streaming: A masterful F. Murray Abraham in “Beckett Briefs,” and Christopher Walken and Susan Sarandon in a take on “Streetcar.”
content: When Gavin Creel died of a rare form of cancer last fall, at the age of 48, he left behind an artistic and emotional hole — he was a beloved presence onstage, especially in musical theater, with an easy wit, a sure flair for physical comedy and an old-fashioned elegance. One of his last large-scale endeavors was the musical “Walk on Through: Confessions of a Museum Novice,” for which he wrote the book and score, and which he performed in a run at MCC Theater in 2023. The show, which The New York Times’s Michael Paulson described as “a passion project” in his obituary for Creel, allowed the actor to venture into soul-searching as he explored his (very new) relationship with the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Fortunately, that institution, which had commissioned the project, keeps a capture of an October 2021 performance on YouTube.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Federal Budget Ax Threatens Contractors, but Could Also Be an Opportunity
description: By cutting federal employees, the Trump administration may increase its reliance on firms that take in billions through government contracts.
content: A contracting firm called Leidos took in more than $16 billion in revenue last year, most of it through contracts with federal agencies like the Department of Veterans Affairs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: For Parents of Babies Near Measles Outbreaks, a Painful Waiting Game
description: Infants are at higher risk of complications from the measles but can’t be vaccinated right away.
content: Since the West Texas measles outbreak began in late January, Dr. Ana Montanez, a pediatrician in Lubbock, has had some difficult conversations with families.
source.name: The New York Times

source.name: The New York Times

description: Zohran Mamdani, Zellnor Myrie and Jessica Ramos are ping-ponging between New York City and Albany as they divide their time between legislating and campaigning.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Woolfe
title: Dudamel Leads a Premiere by a Youthful Ravel. Not Bad for a Kid.

source.name: The New York Times

title: JD Vance Is Booed at a Kennedy Center Concert After Trump’s Takeover
description: The vice president and his wife were booed as they took their seats for a National Symphony Orchestra concert of music by Shostakovich and Stravinsky.
content: It was supposed to be a moment of celebration: Vice President JD Vance was attending a concert at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington on Thursday evening for the first time since President Trump’s stunning takeover of the institution.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: An Animated Spider-Man for Every Era
description: The superhero has been the subject of many different animated TV shows dating back to the 1960s. Here’s how he has evolved.
content: When “Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse” hit theaters in 2018, it served as a delicacy for longtime fans, who found in the film clever allusions to the vast history of Spider-Man comics and animated series. “Into the Spider-Verse” and its sequel, “Spider-Man: Across the Spider-Verse,” was full of Easter eggs plucked from several eras of Spidey shows, many of which have been revered (and some maligned) over the years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Herman Graf, Who Helped Sell ‘Tropic of Cancer,’ Dies at 91
description: A major figure in independent publishing, he promoted Henry Miller’s once-banned book and helped make “A Confederacy of Dunces” a best seller after the author’s death.
content: Herman Graf, a major and intrepid figure in independent publishing who sold copies of Henry Miller’s novel “Tropic of Cancer” to bookstores after it was embroiled in a legal fight over whether it was obscene, died on Feb. 27 at his home in Flushing, Queens. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why China Is Worried About Trump’s Tariffs on Mexico

content: Officials in Beijing are increasingly worried that President Trump’s tariffs on Mexico may be the start of a broad campaign to force developing countries around the world to choose between trade with the United States or with China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff
title: ‘You’re Tough’: How Mexico’s President Won Trump’s Praise
description: A scientist and leftist with limited foreign policy experience, Claudia Sheinbaum seems to have connected with President Trump with her calm demeanor and toughness on the border.
content: With a trade war brewing, President Trump gave the Mexican president a sign of grudging respect: “You’re tough,” he told her in a phone call last month, according to four people with knowledge of the exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

title: SpaceX Launches NASA’s Crew-10 Mission to the I.S.S.

source.name: The New York Times

title: China Condemns Panama Canal Deal, Asserting a Right to Influence the Region

content: The Chinese government has strongly criticized a planned deal by a Hong Kong conglomerate to sell ports in Panama and elsewhere to an investment group led by an American asset manager, warning that the deal would deprive China of needed influence over key shipping routes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: An ‘In Like a Lion, Out Like a Lamb’ Playlist
description: Prepare for spring with songs from the Yeah Yeah Yeahs, Lion Babe, Buddy Guy and others.
content: Early March is such a tease, occasionally giving us a fleeting preview of desperately desired springtime — only to snatch it away with yet another dreary, blustery, 30-something-degree day. You know the saying: “In like a lion, out like a lamb.” Since we’ve finally almost reached that fabled calendrical turning point in the middle of the month, I thought I’d put together a playlist that goes in like a lion and out like a lamb.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Alex Stern, Devon Taylor, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Chris Wood, Mark Zemel, Dave Mayers, Sophie Erickson, Felice Leon and Brooke Minters
title: Two Astronauts on an 8-Day Mission That Turned Into a 9-Month Odyssey
description: An interview with Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore, whose planned short mission to space turned into an adventure lasting much, much longer.
content: A spacecraft malfunction in June kept the NASA astronauts Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore on the International Space Station for more than nine months. They are scheduled to return home in the next few days.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse and Catie Edmondson
title: Under G.O.P., Congress Cedes Power to Trump, Eroding Its Influence

content: The Republican-led Congress isn’t just watching the Trump administration gobble up its constitutional powers. It is enthusiastically turning them over to the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What the Alluring ‘She-Wolf’ of Brazilian Literature Wanted Kids to See
description: In her children’s stories, Clarice Lispector disguised philosophical questions in cheerful, kooky fables about exuberant animals with places to be.
content: Prickly, eccentric, endlessly complex — the Brazilian novelist Clarice Lispector (1920-77) has remained a bundle of contradictions years after her death.
source.name: The New York Times

title: F.D.A. Issues Warning About Galaxy Gas and Other Nitrous Products
description: The agency is advising people to avoid misusing or inhaling the products that are marketed as whipped cream chargers but have been used as recreational drugs.

title: As Trump Attacks Elite Colleges, Their Usual Allies Are Nowhere in Sight

content: In a very short time, Mahmoud Khalil, the former Columbia University graduate student and pro-Palestinian activist who was questionably detained by federal immigration officials, has become a symbol of the Trump administration’s escalating antagonism toward elite universities. Columbia finds itself up against the impression that whatever it has done to combat what it perceived as antisemitism — suppressing campus protests of the war in Gaza with the help of the police; evicting and expelling rallying students; severing ties with a law professor who had been a vocal supporter of the Palestinian cause — it has not been nearly punitive enough.

title: The Blood Moon Rises: A Total Lunar Eclipse

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Science Amid Chaos: What Worked During the Pandemic? What Failed?
description: As the coronavirus spread, researchers worldwide scrambled to find ways to keep people safe. Some efforts were misguided. Others saved millions of lives.
content: Until 2020, few Americans needed to think about how viruses spread or how the human immune system works. The pandemic offered a painful crash course. Sometimes, it seemed that the science was evolving as quickly as the virus itself.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Department of Homeland Security officials conducted the search as the Trump administration sought to deport a former student and pro-Palestinian activist.

content: Oklahomans on Saturday were assessing the damage wrought by dozens of significant fires that swept across the state, fueled by dry vegetation and hurricane-force winds that created dangerous conditions from the Texas Panhandle all the way to Iowa.

On Jan. 6, he announced his intention to step down with polls showing most Canadians deeply unhappy with the state of their country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Marlise Simons

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Adopted Cousin’s Biological Parents Were Siblings. Do I Tell Her?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on divulging a family secret.
content: I have been living with a secret for close to 55 years. My first cousin, whom I am very close with, was adopted from a Catholic orphanage in Italy and brought back to the United States when we were both young. Our mothers are sisters. My cousin has always known she was adopted, but she does not know the circumstances of the adoption. Many years ago, my mother told me in confidence that my cousin’s biological parents were brother and sister. The only people who knew this, besides myself, were my aunt and uncle who adopted her, and my parents, who were her godparents.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Senators Grill Oz on Medicaid Cuts and Medicare Changes
description: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the TV celebrity, dodged queries about Republican plans to cut health insurance for the poor, and emerged unscathed on his ties to major industries.
content: In a hearing on Friday, senators pressed Dr. Mehmet Oz, the TV celebrity nominated to head Medicare and Medicaid, on Republican-led proposals that would significantly affect the health care coverage for nearly half of all Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer, Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
title: A Close Elon Musk Friend Joins His Effort on Social Security
description: The involvement of Antonio Gracias, an investor who has known Elon Musk for two decades, suggests that Mr. Musk has made overhauling the Social Security Administration a priority.
content: A private equity investor who is one of Elon Musk’s closest confidants has taken a new role in the Social Security Administration, a development that could be politically combustible given the program’s popularity with voters and Mr. Musk’s apparent intent to make major changes at the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kevin Peraino
title: Making America Red-Scared Again
description: In “Red Scare,” Clay Risen shows how culture in the United States is still driven by the political paranoia of the 1950s.
content: When the end came for Joe McCarthy, it was Edward R. Murrow who delivered the knockout blow. On his CBS program “See It Now,” Murrow ran damning footage of the red-baiting Wisconsin senator, who appeared hectoring and disheveled to viewers. Murrow proclaimed that McCarthy’s “primary achievement has been in confusing the public mind.” The senator’s reputation never recovered from Murrow’s nationally televised exposé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rosalie R. Radomsky
title: On Good Footing After a Polo Tournament
description: A few months after Dr. Orion Mercaitis leased a polo pony from Olivia Stringer in Aiken, S.C., their relationship took off at a gallop.
content: Even before Dr. Orion Paul Mercaitis saw Olivia Louise Stringer, he heard her trying to get a fractious horse to settle down in October 2023 in the back of a trailer at New Haven Farm in Aiken, S.C.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Oreskes
title: Ocasio-Cortez Lashes Out at Schumer Over His Support for G.O.P. Measure
description: Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez criticized Senator Chuck Schumer for siding with Republicans on a plan to avert a government shutdown. Her tough language drew talk of a primary challenge.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, is facing a torrent of criticism for choosing to vote with his Republican counterparts to head off a government shutdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Fortney
title: Could This Be the End of the Party in Dimes Square?
description: The rejection of one bar’s sidewalk seating permit may be a sign of what’s to come.
content: On Wednesday, the New York City Council convened to vote on matters of critical importance: organic waste collection, blockchain technology, the upcoming mayoral race and 18 red bistro chairs that dot the corner of Canal and Ludlow Streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Kevin Drum, Influential Early Political Blogger, Dies at 66
description: Writing on his own and for Washington Monthly and Mother Jones, he earned a reputation as a serious policy thinker. He also invented Friday cat blogging.
content: Kevin Drum, who gave up his day job in software marketing to write online about politics, policy and his cats, quickly becoming a key figure in the vanguard of center-left bloggers during the genre’s heyday in the early 2000s, died on March 7. He was 66.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kaitlin Menza
title: Bonding Over Books and Long Car Rides
description: Shannon Wu and John Sanders attended the same book festival in Washington, but didn’t meet until they connected on a dating app.
content: “Guess where this photo was taken” was the prompt John Sasscer Sanders Jr. gave alongside a photo on his Hinge dating profile. The image captured Mr. Sanders at a book-signing event for the sociologist Matthew Desmond during the 2023 National Book Festival in Washington.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Senior Islamic State Leader Killed in Joint Iraqi-U.S. Operation, Iraq Says
description: The killing comes as the group has been reconstituting in Syria, carrying out more attacks than at any time since it lost control of its territory nearly six years ago.
content: An airstrike killed a senior Islamic State leader believed to be the head of the group in Iraq and Syria on Friday, in a joint Iraqi and U.S. operation using intelligence from both countries, Iraq’s prime minister said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman and Adam Rasgon
title: Hamas Says It’s Willing to Free American Israeli Captive, but Deal Is in Doubt
description: Hamas said it agreed to release Edan Alexander and turn over the bodies of four other hostages. But both the White House and Israel said Hamas wasn’t serious, suggesting a deal wasn’t close.
content: The White House accused Hamas of dragging its feet on engaging with the latest U.S. cease-fire proposal for Gaza and demanded the immediate release of Edan Alexander, an American Israeli soldier held in Gaza for more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Justices to Consider Request to Lift Nationwide Pause on Birthright Citizenship Order
description: The justices requested responses by early April from the states and groups who had challenged the executive order.
content: The Supreme Court on Friday afternoon requested responses from states and groups that have challenged the constitutionality of the president’s order ending birthright citizenship for the children of undocumented immigrants and foreign residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Norwegian Ski Jumpers Suspended for Illegal Alterations to Their Suits
description: The skiers tried to find an extra edge to fly farther by adjusting the crotch of their suits. “We regret it like dogs,” the team’s coach said.
content: There is a long tradition of teams trying to get an edge in ski jumping, making tweaks to equipment to try to gain a few feet in distance, or even a few inches. But a recent alteration to the crotch area of a team’s ski suits went too far.Five Norwegian ski jumpers and three officials were suspended by the International Ski and Snowboard Federation this week, accused of cheating after altering the crotches of the team’s ski suits. Some of the officials soon confessed to the scheme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: Father Accused of Fatally Beating His 2-Month-Old Daughter
description: Marlon Rabanales-Pretzantzin was charged with second-degree murder in a Long Island court on Thursday. Authorities said he had acknowledged hurting the child.
content: A Long Island man has been accused of killing his infant daughter, the Nassau County police said on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Butters
title: Trump’s Tariff Threats Are Driving Carmakers Crazy
description: Automakers looked forward to his return to the presidency, only to find themselves struggling under the weight of his tariff threats.
content: Since returning to office, Donald Trump has embarked on a shock-and-awe policy blitz that has paralyzed not only his political rivals but also an automotive industry that had largely welcomed his return.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes and David E. Sanger
title: Trump Administration Opens Leak Investigations
description: Tulsi Gabbard, the director of national intelligence, said she intended to hold officials who released information “accountable.”
content: The Trump administration has opened its first known investigations into what it called “politically motivated leaks,” fulfilling promises to pursue the sources of stories involving national security revelations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Palmer and Federico Borella
title: Vroom! Touring Italy’s Supercar Factories
description: In the country’s “Motor Valley,” racecar enthusiasts can admire, and even drive, Maseratis, Lamborghinis, Ferraris and more.
content: It costs about 14 euros, or about $15, per minute to drive a rented Lamborghini on the public roads of northern Italy’s Emilia-Romagna region. This feels especially exorbitant in a place where a couple of coins buys a glass of world-class wine. Even more grating, however, is that the experience is actually worth the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Barry Singer
title: Anne Kaufman Schneider, 99, Ardent Keeper of Her Father’s Plays, Dies
description: She shepherded the works of George S. Kaufman from the 20th century into the next, encouraging regional theater productions and helping to steer two of them to Broadway.
content: Anne Kaufman Schneider, who shepherded the plays of her father, George S. Kaufman, a titan of 20th-century American theatrical wit, into the 21st century with an acerbic sagacity all her own, died on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Martin Fackler
title: In Japan, a Journalist Takes a Stand by Striking Out on His Own
description: Makoto Watanabe quit a major newspaper after it retracted a scoop. Now he runs an investigative nonprofit that does not shy away from challenging authority.
content: Makoto Watanabe has never forgotten the day when his previous employer, one of Japan’s biggest newspapers, retreated from its biggest investigative scoop about the Fukushima nuclear disaster: that workers had fled the plant against orders from the plant’s manager.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lidija Hilje
title: Is My Husband a Doormat?
description: How a personality test changed our marriage.
content: Nearly four years ago, at our home in Zadar, Croatia, during what had been no more than ordinary bickering, my husband yelled unimaginable words: “You’ve been abusing me for 20 years!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Young Democrats’ Anger Boils Over as Schumer Retreats on Shutdown
description: A generational divide, seen in newer lawmakers’ impatience with bipartisanship and for colleagues who don’t understand new media, has emerged as one of the deepest rifts within the party.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer’s sudden decision on Thursday to support a Republican-written bill to avert a government shutdown so enraged his fellow Democrats that some were already talking about primary challenges to the 74-year-old Democratic leader from New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Schumer, Facing Backlash for Not Forcing a Shutdown, Says He’ll Take ‘the Bullets’
description: Privately, many Senate Democrats conceded that their leader was doing his job by protecting his members from a tough vote and making a politically painful decision. But the backlash from his party was intense.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the minority leader, defended himself on Friday in the face of a Democratic backlash to his decision to vote with Republicans for a stopgap spending bill to stave off a government shutdown, saying he was willing to take political hits to protect his members and their constituents from a longer-term disaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Prang
title: The Climate Fix: Nuclear Waste Finds Its Forever Home
description: Finland may soon become the first country to develop a permanent way to store spent nuclear fuel by burying it in tunnels deep underground.
content: Editor’s note: The Climate Fix is our twice-a-month guide to the most important solutions to climate change across the world. Have comments about what we should cover? Email us at Climateforward@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chuck Schumer
title: Chuck Schumer: Trump and Musk Would Love a Shutdown. We Must Not Give Them One.
description: A government shutdown would lead to real pain for the American people.
content: Over the past two months, the United States has confronted a bitter truth: The federal government has been taken over by a nihilist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Damien
title: $3.5 Million Settlement in Sacramento Jail Death
description: The fatal overdose of a homeless man at a Sacramento County jail is one of multiple deaths in which staff have been accused of medical neglect.
content: The family of a man who died from an overdose in a Sacramento County jail after being left unattended for hours have agreed to a $3.5 million settlement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hank Sanders
title: Plane Fire at Denver Airport Forces Passengers to Evacuate Onto Wing
description: The flight had been diverted to the airport after experiencing “engine vibrations,” the authorities said. Twelve people were taken to hospitals.
content: An American Airlines plane that was diverted to Denver International Airport on Thursday evening after experiencing “engine vibrations” caught fire while taxiing to a gate, prompting the evacuation of dozens of passengers, according to the Federal Aviation Administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: What on Earth Is Gavin Newsom Doing?
description: Democrats are desperate for leaders who will fight on their behalf, not flatter their enemies.
content: I was open to the idea behind Gavin Newsom’s new podcast, in which the California governor has been breaking out of his political bubble to talk at length with right-wing media stars such as Charlie Kirk and Steve Bannon. Democrats need to get better at speaking to people who don’t share their assumptions and at long-form conversations requiring improvisation and spontaneity. They need to be willing to take risks and to use conflict to generate attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Bird Flu Kills 2 Pet Cats in New York City, Officials Say
description: Health authorities say the threat of infection for people remained low even amid the spread of H5N1 virus among birds and cattle nationally.
content: Two pet cats in New York City died after being infected with bird flu, health officials said on Friday, a sign of the increased spread of a virus that has decimated chickens and cattle and sickened dozens of people nationally.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan and Zach Montague
title: Judges Have Ordered Federal Workers Back on the Job. Now What?
description: Fired employees expressed excitement about the prospect of reinstatement, as well as back pay. But there’s no template for rehiring en masse.
content: Last month, thousands of employees with probationary status across the federal government were fired by the Trump administration in an extraordinary and coordinated move. On Thursday, a pair of court rulings called for agencies to reinstate an untold number of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: DOGE Could Gut a Piece of Trump Family History
description: In the heart of Seattle, a national park memorializes the grit of the Klondike gold rush, where the president’s grandfather built his early wealth. The park is now under threat.
content: In 1891, as Seattle was rebuilding from a catastrophic fire that had destroyed nearly all of its central business district, Frederick Trump arrived looking to find his fortune.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eoin Higgins
title: How a Quack TV Doctor Made It to Washington
description: A once-respected surgeon found fame and fortune as medicine’s biggest iconoclast. Now he’s on the cusp of power to help shape American public health.
content: Before medical contrarianism became intrinsic to his identity, Dr. Mehmet Oz appeared motivated by curiosity rather than opportunism. Arriving at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in 1986 to follow in his father’s footsteps and become a cardiothoracic surgeon, Dr. Oz became well respected in the field. But much to the chagrin of administrators and peers, he also showed a penchant for questionable medicine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: TEFAF Returns With Majesty in an Uncertain Market
description: The fair has a jewel of a 16th-century illuminated manuscript, and other museum-quality items, but fewer standouts over all. Sales were still brisk.
content: A medieval manuscript unseen for 60 years, hand-painted by the renowned French illuminator Jean Pichore and his workshop, is one of the most spectacular exhibits at the 38th annual edition of the TEFAF Maastricht fair, which previewed to invited guests on Thursday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,365
description: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Saturday, March 15, 2025.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Alan K. Simpson, a Folksy Republican Force in the Senate, Dies at 93
description: A plain-spoken lawmaker from Wyoming, he balanced his conservative views with moderate stands on abortion rights, gay marriage and immigration reform.
content: Alan K. Simpson, a plain-spoken former Republican senator from Wyoming who championed immigration reforms and conservative candidates for the Supreme Court while fighting running battles with women’s groups, environmentalists and the press, died on Friday in hospice in Cody, Wyo. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Vora
title: A Love Worth an Early Retirement and a Cross-Country Move
description: Dr. Raymond Parungao and Andrew Chen have had a bicoastal relationship for most or their 15 years together.
content: Dr. Raymond Joseph Parungao and Andrew Chih-Hao Chen were attracted to each other the instant their eyes locked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Halperin
title: Enemies in Battle Over ‘LOVE’ Artist Bury the Hatchet
description: Can two rivals, bringing Robert Indiana’s long-hidden work into the light, reboot his legacy for a new generation?
content: Inside Kasmin Gallery in Manhattan, more than a dozen employees huddled like a football team. It was late February and the gallery’s president, Nick Olney, was giving his staff a pep talk before his version of the big game: the opening of the first New York exhibition of work by Robert Indiana since the artist’s death in 2018. Standing next to his celebrated “LOVE” sculpture, Olney laid out the game plan. The goal: a reboot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Bociurkiw
title: What Zelensky Does Next
description: Different sides of the war in Ukraine reach for different, simple narratives about Mr. Zelensky. The truth has always been more complicated.
content: My most vivid memory of Volodymyr Zelensky’s campaign for president of Ukraine was his debate with President Petro Poroshenko in April 2019. Mr. Poroshenko, a tycoon who made his fortune in chocolate, talked patriotically about the army, language and faith. Mr. Zelensky, a hugely popular comedian and actor who played a fictional president on TV, shot back that he was an outsider ready to break the system. His gruff energy and charisma easily outshined Mr. Poroshenko. Days later, the presidency was his.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Dr. Sheldon Greenfield, Who Exposed Gaps in Health Care, Dies at 86
description: The author of numerous studies, he urged patients to question their physicians and expressed concern about cancer treatment for older adults.
content: Dr. Sheldon Greenfield, whose pioneering research found that older patients with breast and pancreatic cancer got subpar treatment and that patients who grill their doctors during consultations receive better care, died on Feb. 26 at his home in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Jaffe
title: Hegseth Closes Pentagon Office Focused on Future Wars
description: The Office of Net Assessment opened more than 50 years ago and developed concepts for possible conflict with U.S. adversaries, including China.
content: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth ordered the shuttering of the Office of Net Assessment, a small, often secretive and sometimes opaque office that for more than 50 years has helped the Pentagon’s most senior leaders think about the future of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage, Ken Bensinger and Allison McCann
title: Draft List for New Travel Ban Proposes Trump Target 43 Countries
description: A draft circulating inside the administration lists three tiers of countries whose citizens may face restrictions on entering the United States.
content: The Trump administration is considering targeting the citizens of as many as 43 countries as part of a new ban on travel to the United States that would be broader than the restrictions imposed during President Trump’s first term, according to officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cassidy Randall
title: Why Is Trump So Obsessed With McKinley?
description: At least a dozen other mountains and ridges in the U.S. already carry the name McKinley.
content: In 1896, a gold prospector named William Dickey led a journey through what he called the “wonderful wilderness” of Alaska, where he glimpsed an enormous mountain that compelled his “unbounded admiration.” When he emerged from the Alaskan interior, the first news he heard was that William McKinley, the former governor of Ohio, had received the Republican nomination for president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Graydon Carter and the Golden Age of New York City Media
description: The former Vanity Fair editor reflects on an era’s power moves and expense-account adventures in a new memoir.
content: Lorne. Graydon. Keith. Three abiding kings of New York City’s cultural life are the subjects of new books. Lorne is Lorne Michaels, the creator of “Saturday Night Live,” who is examined under the stereo microscope that is Susan Morrison’s biography, “Lorne.” Graydon is Graydon Carter, a co-founder of the stinging magazine Spy in the 1980s and the editor of Vanity Fair during its plumpest and happiest decades, whose memoir is our topic today. Keith is Keith McNally, the proprietor of that consummate French bistro Balthazar — which is so well run, so well lit and so well victualed that surely one idea of a good death is to deliquesce in one of its red leather banquettes — who has a memoir out soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: A Mathematical ‘Fever Dream’ Hits the Road
description: Meet “Mathemalchemy,” a traveling math-meets-art installation coming eventually to a dimension near you.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is This a ‘Negative World’ for Christians?
description: Readers react to a profile of the Christian author Aaron Renn. Also: The link between poverty and health; absent ex-presidents; solo female travelers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Learning a Shared Love Language — One That Includes Signing
description: Jerald Creer, who is deaf, and Kent Williams met on a cruise ship in 2009. It took almost 15 years and a card game for them to fall in love.
content: Jerald Jerard Creer and Kent Michael Williams chalk up the almost 15-year delay in becoming a couple to a struggle to communicate — one that had nothing to do with Mr. Creer’s Deafness.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 14, 2025
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 14, 2025.
content: A news analysis article on Thursday about shifting political winds in the Philippines misstated the day when President Ferdinand R. Marcos Jr. received the arrest warrant for his predecessor, Rodrigo Duterte. It was on Tuesday, not Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colby Smith
title: U.S. Consumer Sentiment Drops as Inflation Anxiety Soars
description: A new survey from the University of Michigan shows Americans bracing for economic pain as tariffs and policy uncertainty bite.
content: Policy uncertainty and tariff whiplash are making consumers less confident about the economic outlook and more worried about inflation, new data from the University of Michigan showed on Friday, the latest evidence that Americans are bracing for pain in President Trump’s second term.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Michael Crowley
title: G7 Foreign Ministers Keep Tensions in Check to Agree on Ukraine Policy
description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio found himself among allies in a fraught moment after President Trump’s tariff policies.
content: Despite high tensions between the Trump administration and some of America’s closest allies over tariffs and Ukraine, foreign ministers from the Group of 7 industrialized democracies who were meeting this week in Canada forged common ground in a communiqué that glossed over many of their sharp differences.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Bringing Astronauts Home
description: We explain why two astronauts were stuck in orbit for so long.
content: Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore thought they were taking off for a couple weeks in space. Their mission was to test Boeing’s new Starliner spacecraft and then head home. It didn’t go as planned. Nine months later, the NASA astronauts will finally return to Earth from the International Space Station next week if there are no other hitches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reed Abelson and Susanne Craig
title: Dr. Oz to Face Pointed Questions on Medicare and Medicaid Before Senate Panel
description: The Senate Finance Committee holds a confirmation hearing on Friday for Dr. Mehmet Oz, the TV celebrity who is nominated to run major health programs for older Americans and the poor.
content: Dr. Mehmet Oz, the TV celebrity doctor, is expected to face a tense confirmation hearing on Friday, with Democratic senators planning to question how he would oversee Medicare and Medicaid now that Republicans and the Trump administration are weighing significant changes affecting millions of Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin George Andrews
title: Mars Gets a Close-Up and a Photo Bomb as Europe’s Hera Mission Swoops Past
description: The Red Planet and its tiny moon Deimos were recorded at a very near distance as the asteroid-chasing spacecraft completed a flyby on Wednesday.
content: An asteroid-chasing spacecraft just swung past Mars on Wednesday. As it zipped by, it took hundreds of shots of the Red Planet, as well as several snaps of Deimos, one of the two small Martian moons.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: To Create a ‘Portrait of the Modern Dandy,’ the Met Enlisted a Superstar
description: The 29-year-old fashion photographer Tyler Mitchell had his own ideas about how to shoot the catalog for the museum’s spring Costume Institute show.
content: Last year, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art invited a young photographer to shoot its highly anticipated spring 2025 fashion exhibition, the museum got something it probably wasn’t expecting: a counteroffer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Postal Service Reaches Deal With Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency
description: The U.S. Postal Service has long struggled with its finances. President Trump and Mr. Musk have both suggested it should be privatized.
content: The leader of the U.S. Postal Service said in a letter to lawmakers on Thursday that he had reached an agreement with Elon Musk’s cost-cutting team allowing it to help in “identifying and achieving further efficiencies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mujib Mashal
title: ‘People Will Die’: Trump Aid Cuts Threaten Refugees’ Survival, U.N. Says
description: At the world’s largest refugee camp, for Rohingya people in Bangladesh, the food allowance per person is set to fall to just $6 per month, far below what aid officials say is required for survival.
content: More than a million people in the world’s largest refugee camp could soon be left with too little food for survival.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Francis Made ‘Pray for Me’ His Signature. Now Many Are.
description: The pope’s words emphasized his humility and belief that simple acts of devotion could unite the church. His illness has made the appeal more urgent than ever.
content: When Pope Francis first appeared to the world on the balcony of St. Peter’s Basilica, he humbly requested that the faithful “pray for me.” Those simple words became the punctuation marks of his pontificate, as he ended practically all his speeches, greetings, weekly benedictions and casual conversations with the appeal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush, Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Tyler Pager
title: In Speech to Justice Dept., Trump Airs Grievances Against His Enemies
description: The president, once the target of federal prosecution, says he wants to combat “weaponization” of the department, even as he uses its powers to punish enemies and reward allies.
content: President Trump’s triumphal entry into Justice Department headquarters on Friday darkened into an acid recitation of grievances against his enemies, as he demonstrated his power over a department that had tried and failed to hold him to account.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Normani Is Engaged — With a Little Help From Her Famous Matchmakers
description: The R&B artist and the newly traded Pittsburgh Steeler DeKaylin “DK” Metcalf are a success story for friends playing matchmaker. The pair were introduced by Ciara and Russell Wilson in 2022.
content: Normani and DeKaylin Metcalf have kept their relationship mostly low-key, but that changed on Thursday when Mr. Metcalf, an N.F.L. wide receiver, announced their engagement — at a news conference announcing his recent trade, of all places.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: Famous Climate Observatory’s Lease May End Because of DOGE
description: NOAA, the nation’s leading climate science agency, may lose dozens of offices, including one that is key to the Mauna Loa Observatory in Hawaii.
content: On the flanks of the largest active volcano on Earth, the Mauna Loa Observatory tracks the amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere that are warming the planet, and has been doing so since 1958.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Measles Can Damage the Immune System for Years
description: An infection can also leave children and adults with other long-term health problems.
content: As more measles cases emerge around the country, doctors say they’re concerned that those infected may be at risk of long-term health complications.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Maria Varenikova
title: Putin Demands Ukrainian Troops in Kursk Region of Russia Surrender
description: Talks in Moscow with a U.S. special envoy indicated that Russia was keen to keep negotiating with the United States over Ukraine.
content: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Friday insisted that Ukraine order some of its forces to surrender to Russia, a striking demand made hours after President Trump said the United States had “very good and productive” discussions with Mr. Putin about a potential cease-fire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: How a Russian Mobster Stalked an Iranian Dissident in Brooklyn
description: Khalid Mehdiyev was sent to America to establish a beachhead for his gang. The organization then gave him a mission: Kill Masih Alinejad.
content: Khalid Mehdiyev returned a phone call in the summer of 2022 from a fellow member of the Russian mob, Polad Omarov. They had been collaborating on a project, Mr. Mehdiyev said, extorting a grocery store owner in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Kaye
title: Stocks Rebound After S&P Falls Into Correction, but Tariff Unease Lingers
description: The gains on Friday were the biggest daily jump since President Trump’s election. But they weren’t enough to overcome steep tariff-induced losses earlier in the week, and the S&P 500 remained in negative territory.
content: Stocks on Wall Street rallied on Friday to their biggest daily jump since President Trump’s election, bouncing off a drop that had left the market in a correction after weeks of selling. But the gains weren’t enough to overcome the steep losses from earlier in the week, and the S&P 500 remained in negative territory for the week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Is Trump ‘Detoxing’ the Economy or Poisoning It?
description: The Financial Times columnist Gillian Tett discusses what Trump’s plan to ‘detox’ the economy is actually meant to achieve.
content: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing to the show on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A New Route for Half Marathon Runners
description: On Sunday, the runners will go over the Brooklyn Bridge for the first time because of construction in Lower Manhattan.
content: Good morning. It’s Friday. Today we’ll look at why the New York City Half Marathon on Sunday will follow a new route. We’ll also get details on a protest at Trump Tower by a progressive Jewish group in support of a Palestinian activist whom the Trump administration wants to deport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: University of Minnesota, Under Federal Scrutiny, Limits Its Political Speech

title: In ‘Meanwhile,’ a Nation Remembers to Breathe

content: The makers of “Meanwhile” (in theaters) describe it as a “docu-poem,” which is a bold choice: Not many people encounter feature-length nonfiction poetry onscreen. But in about 90 minutes, the director Catherine Gund fuses work from multidisciplinary artists, words from the author Jacqueline Woodson, soundscapes by the musician Meshell Ndegeocello, archival footage and interviews in a way that elevates each of those elements, crafting an exploration of Black resilience. If in verbal poetry the meaning often resides in surprising juxtapositions, words used in ways that surprise and unsettle us, then this is, indeed, poetry.
